text: Try:
You'll see if you haven't put anything in it that it'll be size 0.
With cookie = [] you can continuously add elements to the list but it's initialized empty.
cookie = [] creates empty list with no data, so no indexes here.
You need to fill cookie with some data first (e.g.
using cookie.append(some_data)).
How about:

code:
cookies = []

...

for cookie in cookies:
    if cookie > 5:
         break

text: You can't really have a list with no ending that in your case presumably has only zeros in it.
You can however create a list with  11  zeros:
Or create something that returns 0 if you access it at an index if you haven't put anything else in there:
Note that this is not a list but a map.
foo = [] creates an empty list, not a list with no ending.
Any index access will fail on an empty list.
To check the length of a list, use len(mylist).
The length of an empty list is 0, and indices are zero-based.
So:

code:
cookie = []
len(cookie) == 0
cookie[0] ## will raise IndexError

cookie.append('something')
len(cookie) == 1
cookie[0] ## will return 'something'

text: See the list docs
foo=[] does not create a list with no ending.
Instead, it creates an empty list.
You could do

code:
for i in range(0, len(foo)):
    if(cookie[i]>5):
        break

text: Or you could do

code:
for c in cookie:
    if c>5:
        break
